metadata.case_name: State of Bihar & Anr. v. Kundan Singh & Ors.

facts.text: Respondents owned an area of 0.12 acre of land in village Bermo No. 18 in the district of Hazaribagh.
Land required for construction of Aerial Rope-way for Bokaro Thermal Power Plant.
Declaration under s. 4 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 made on August 9, 1952.
Property consists of two buildings: main structure and out-houses together with open space in front.
Government acquired space of 50 ft in width for electric wire, including portion of open space and out-houses.
Land Acquisition Officer fixed compensation at Rs. 4,451/5/6 for land and out-houses.

Respondents applied for reference under s. 18, claiming additional compensation: Rs. 21,765/8/- spent on principal building and loss of monthly rent Rs. 160/-, due to contiguous lands/buildings not acquired making them useless; referrable to s. 23(3).
Deputy Commissioner made reference, noting claim for additional compensation due to loss from non-acquisition of contiguous property.
Kundan Singh (respondent No. 1) gave evidence before District Judge that on October 22, 1952, he applied for acquisition of other quarters as they were contiguous and useless.
District Judge held narrow strip left affected utility of larger building and unacquired land; awarded additional Rs. 1,000/- besides LAO amount.
Respondents appealed to Patna High Court under s. 54, claiming rope-way spoiled main building, so out-houses could not be acquired without main building; sought direction to acquire main building.
Appellants contended before High Court: s. 49 plea not open in s. 18 reference appeal; point not raised before LAO or District Judge.
High Court rejected contentions, directed Land Acquisition Officer to acquire remaining area and building, assess compensation, deduct Rs. 1,000/- awarded by District Judge.
No application under s. 49 produced or shown to High Court; District Judge did not accept s. 49 plea.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court could entertain a plea under s. 49 of the Land Acquisition Act in an appeal arising from reference proceedings under s. 18.
Whether respondents had made an application under s. 49 before the Land Acquisition Officer made the award.

petitioner_arguments.text: Plea under s. 49 not open in appeal from s. 18 reference; such plea foreign to s. 18 enquiry and should be under s. 49 proceedings.
No application under s. 49 made before Land Acquisition Officer or District Judge; respondents' reference claim was under s. 23(1) third/fourth clauses.

respondent_arguments.text: Claim in s. 18 reference petition (para I d) showed reliance on s. 49; contiguous property not acquired caused huge loss; entitled to acquisition of whole property including main building.
Rope-way completely spoiled main building; Land Acquisition Officer could not acquire out-houses without main building.

court_reasoning.text: No evidence respondents made s. 49 application before award; District Judge rejected it implicitly, treated claim under s. 23; no such application produced.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Respondents' s. 18 petition claimed under s. 23, not s. 49.

court_reasoning.text: Scope of s. 18 reference limited to measurement, amount of compensation, persons entitled, apportionment; court considers s. 23 factors therein, but s. 49 claim separate proceeding before award.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S. 49 prohibits partial acquisition if owner desires whole before award; distinct from s. 18.

court_reasoning.text: S. 49(1) ban operates before award under s. 11; owner must object post ss. 4/6 notifications but pre-award; post-award, claim under s. 23 only.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Two alternative remedies: s. 23 additional compensation or pre-award s. 49 full acquisition.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished Narayanaswamy Chettier (special circumstances allowed post-award claim); followed Krishna Das Roy (s. 49 before award).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scheme of s. 49 requires pre-award expression of desire.

holdings.text: High Court erred in allowing s. 49 plea in s. 18 reference appeal; such claim must be raised before award in separate s. 49 proceedings.
No s. 49 application made by respondents before award.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pramatha Nath Mullick v. Secretary of State for India
precedents_cited.relevance: Scope of enquiry under s. 18 limited to four specified objections.

precedents_cited.case_name: Secretary of State for India in Council v. Narayanaswamy Chettier
precedents_cited.relevance: Held s. 49 claim not required before award, but disapproved as contrary to s. 49 scheme (special circumstances there).

precedents_cited.case_name: Krishna Das Roy v. The Land Acquisition Collector of Pabna
precedents_cited.relevance: S. 49 application must be made before award.

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition Act, 1894
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs acquisition proceedings, reference for compensation, scope of enquiries, prohibition on partial acquisition of house if owner desires whole pre-award.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside the Patna High Court order directing acquisition of remaining property under s. 49, and restored the District Judge's order awarding additional Rs. 1,000/- compensation.
outcome.relief_granted: Restoration of District Judge's award of Rs. 4,451/5/6 + Rs. 1,000/-

key_quotes.text: The scope of the enquiry under s. 18(1) is specifically indicated by the section itself.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines limits of s. 18 reference proceedings.

key_quotes.text: A claim under s. 49... cannot be mixed up with a claim which can be made in reference proceedings sent to the Court under s. 18.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies separation of s. 49 and s. 18 remedies.

key_quotes.text: The owner has to express his desire that the whole of his house should be acquired before the award is made.
key_quotes.speaker: court
